Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Melt Viscosities in Silica-undersaturated Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The movement of magma through the Earth, or magma transport, is an important agent of mass and heat transfer within the Earth. The efficiency of magma transport controls the separation of planets into different phases after their formation, the scale and frequency of volcanic eruptions, and the behavior of the planetary crust during mountain building. In turn, how far and how fast magma travels from its source before it hardens and the violence of volcanic eruptions are controlled by viscosity, the measure of magma's resistance to flow. Viscosity is one of the most variable physical properties in geological processes and its magnitude depends on temperature, chemistry, and on the magma's content of volatiles like water, carbon dioxide, and fluorine. Viscosity is subject to change rapidly in response to processes such as the formation of crystals or bubbles in the magma. These processes can cause chemical and thermal changes, leading to temperature and viscosity feedbacks in magmas. Modeling and understanding of geologic processes at all scales therefore requires accurate quantitative determination of magma transport and thermal properties. This can be done experimentally, by a combination of low- (<1000°C) and high-temperature (>1000°C) viscosity measurements and high-temperature (up to 1500°C) heat capacity measurements on the same suite of samples at atmospheric pressure.

For a suite of silica-undersaturated aluminosilicate melts that are analogs for highly-alkalic mafic magmas, the PI and Bates College undergraduate students will quantify the effects of (1) Na-K mixing, of (2) Al/(Al+Si) ratio, and of (3) fluorine on viscosity and heat capacity. The effects of fluorine on viscosity and heat capacity of such melts are especially important to consider as fluorine's abundance correlates positively with the abundance of potassium and has a relatively high solubility at atmospheric conditions. This has implications for the transport behavior of terrestrial magmas that are nominally degassed with respect to other volatiles that are not significantly soluble at atmospheric pressure (e.g., water and carbon dioxide) and also for Martian magmas, which are thought to originate from the melting of a more fluorine-rich source relative to Earth. The results will be modeled using configurational entropy theory, which relates the timescale at which structural changes occur within a fluid (e.g., magma or melt) to the probability of these structural rearrangements. The results from this research will contribute to a better understanding of the chemical controls on viscosity and heat capacity, which in turn allows the construction of better predictive models of magma movement and emplacement in the Earth, and of lava eruption and flow at the Earth's surface.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We determined the effect of the magmatic volatile fluorine (F) on the viscosity and heat capacity of sodium-potassium aluminosilicate melts. Fluorine is an important magmatic volatile known for reducing the viscosity of melts. We tested the magnitude of its effect on melts with varying sodium to potassium ratios as well as varying aluminum to silicon ratios. 

Fluorine reduced the viscosity of all of the melts we measured. For all aluminum to silicon ratios tested, the magnitude of the effect was very similar. The magnitude of the viscosity-reducing effect of fluorine was also very similar across the different sodium to potassium ratios tested, except for melts with very high potassium (greater than 75% potassium relative to total alkali content) which experienced a greater reduction in viscosity. The magnitude of the viscosity reduction for melts with fluorine contents of ~4 wt.% was of the order of 3.5 log units at temperatures of 925 degrees Celcius.  

Modelling based on combined viscosity and heat capacity data showed that the mixing of sodium and potassium in fluorine-free melt is the main source of additional entropy in the system. This is based on the limited dependence of modelling parameters on the aluminum to silicon ratio. Melt viscosity near the glass transition temperature changes at a higher rate for melts with greater aluminum relative to the total amount of aluminum plus silicon present in the melts. This is also true for melts with either high sodium or high potassium compared to melts with mixed sodium and potassium. 

This grant provided summer research and senior thesis research support for 10 undergraduate students at Bates College. Samples from this study are also used for in-class research projects at Bates College.
